title: Dyal Capital Nears Deal for Minority Stake in Sacramento Kings
summary: Proposed deal would give investment firm nearly 5% stake at valuation of $1.5 billion, according to people familiar with the matter. Dyal Capital is nearing a deal to make an investment in the Sacramento Kings National Basketball Association team, according to people familiar with the matter, as the firm works to assemble a portfolio of stakes across the league.

title: Behind Cuba's Covid Uprising
summary: Most poor countries put all hands on deck in this crisis. Havana exports its doctors.. Cubans poured into the streets Sunday to protest the government's handling of the Covid crisis. As the virus races across Cuba, independent lawyers, medical professionals and civil-society groups on the island have begged Havana to allow international humanitarian aid to reach people directly. The regime refuses. Now the crisis is near cataclysmic proportions.

title: Here Come the Climate Protectionists
summary: Europe starts the bidding on CO2 tariffs. Will Biden follow?. Western politicians have failed to persuade their own voters to commit economic suicide by banning fossil fuels, and forget about China, Russia or India. The climate lobby's fallback, which is starting to emerge, is to punish the foreigners and their own consumers with climate tariffs.

title: No More 'Captive Nations' Week?
summary: The White House floats a needless change to a useful diplomatic tool.. President Biden likes to say he wants to restore America's moral leadership in the world, but sometimes it seems his team at the White House wants to change something merely because Donald Trump supported it.

title: California's Power Jam
summary: Unreliable renewables are forcing the state to scramble for electricity.. President Biden wants to spend tens of billions of dollars on transmission lines to transport renewable electricity across states, which he says will improve grid reliability. His climate model of California is showing the limits and risks of this strategy.

title: 'Among the Mosques' Review: From Islamist to British Patriot
summary: Ed Husain once defended Islam in terms of Blair-era multiculturalism. Now he invites Muslims to join the 'British mainstream.'. The future of relations between Muslims and non-Muslims in the United Kingdom may be a troubled one. Ed Husain sounds the alarm in "Among the Mosques: A Journey Across Muslim Britain." The book chronicles his visits to 10 cities. Mr. Husain, a British writer and political adviser, takes us into local mosques for Friday prayers and relates his encounters, planned and unplanned, with local personalities in Muslim communities. Some of the communities he visits exhibit the very best British traditions of tolerance and pluralism, but most do not.

title: To Avert Disaster in Afghanistan, Look to Central Asia
summary: A coming infrastructure conference could lay the groundwork for a new strategy in the region.. American forces have left Afghanistan. Now what? President Biden has yet to settle on the outlines of an approach. What should the U.S. seek to achieve? Who are its partners?

title: In Defense of Limousine Liberals
summary: Wealthy people who call for higher taxes aren't hypocritical. They're selfless.. 'Limousine liberals" have driven full circle-or rather the term has returned to its origins. Coined in 1969 by Mario Procaccino, the Democratic Party's unsuccessful challenger to New York Mayor John Lindsay, the epithet described "hypocritical wealthy do-gooders insulated from the negative fallout of their bad ideas," in historian David Callahan's definition.

title: David Bowie's NYC Apartment Finds Buyer in Less Than a Month
summary: Resume Subscription. After less than a month on the market asking $16.8 million, David Bowie's longtime apartment in downtown Manhattan is in contract to be sold, according to property records and StreetEasy.com.

title: Italy Beats England in Shootout to Win Soccer's European Championship
summary: After extra time finished with the score tied at 1, the Three Lions are haunted by another penalty shootout in a major tournament. LONDON-In England's 55 years of waiting for another crack at a major-tournament final, nothing had caused it more sporting trauma than one of the simplest tasks in soccer: nailing a penalty shot from 12 yards out.

title: Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic Flight Opens Door to Space Tourism
summary: Hourlong trip was aimed at highlighting the safety and potential of sending paying passengers to the edge of space. TRUTH OR CONSEQUENCES, N.M.-Richard Branson reached the edge of space and safely returned to Earth, a trip that marks a turning point in the billionaire entrepreneur's multidecade effort to help create a space-tourism industry.

title: New Heat Wave Blisters the West
summary: Death Valley reached highest temperature recorded in over a century amid scorching conditions this weekend. A new heat wave persisted over the Western U.S. this weekend, bringing record high temperatures across multiple states.

title: Lawmakers to Determine Fate of Infrastructure, Antipoverty Plans
summary: Senators return to Washington with trillions of dollars of spending proposals on the line. WASHINGTON-Democrats are racing to finalize a bipartisan infrastructure deal and set the contours of a broad child-care and education plan, aiming to maintain a delicate agreement with Republicans while simultaneously plowing forward with their own priorities.

title: Ticketless Fans Crash Into Wembley Stadium Before Euro Final Kickoff
summary: Hundreds of fans apparently rushed into the stadium before the England-Italy match Sunday night, creating conflict and confusion. LONDON-Hundreds of ticketless fans rushed into Wembley Stadium here on Sunday evening ahead of England's European Championship final showdown with Italy, causing clashes in the stands and raising fears about security surrounding the game.

title: Economy Week Ahead: U.S. Consumers, Fed Testimony, China GDP
summary: Inflation pressures, both recorded and anticipated, take center stage in the coming week's economic calendar. Inflation is the focus this week with a U.S. report on consumer prices and Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's testimony on Capitol Hill.

title: These Countries Look Ahead to Living With Covid-19
summary: The virus won't go away, but vaccinations show a path to normalcy. A handful of countries, including the U.S., are leading the way toward a future where Covid-19 has faded into the background.

title: 'Black Widow' Tops Box Office, Lifting Prospect of Moviegoing Rebound
summary: Company announces the Marvel film also grossed more than $60 million on Disney+ platform. Finally back in theaters, Hollywood's dominant film franchise posted the biggest opening of the pandemic era as Marvel spinoff "Black Widow" ruled this weekend's box office.

title: Bat Scientists Warn That the World May Never Know Covid-19 Origins
summary: Resume Subscription. Since the start of the Covid-19 pandemic, scientists all over the world have been struggling to pin down the origin of the coronavirus that caused it.

title: Trump Can Win His Case Against Tech Giants
summary: The companies censor on the government's behalf. There's ample precedent for calling it state action.. The media has panned Donald Trump's First Amendment lawsuits against Facebook, Twitter and YouTube: "sure to fail," "as stupid as you'd think," "ridiculous." Mr. Trump's complaint omits important precedents, facts and claims for relief, but there's a strong case to be made that social-media censorship violates the Constitution. If his lawyers do better in court than in their initial filing, Mr. Trump can win.

title: Can Robinhood Ride the Bull?
summary: Let's see how it stands up against three measures of what makes a good IPO.. Robinhood, the commission-free meme-stock dream shop, is going public. There's talk of a bubbly $40 billion valuation. Woohoo! Plus, the company has announced that up to 35% of the new shares in the initial public offering are reserved for its own retail customers. Groundbreaking? I don't know. If Robinhood really is the future of Wall Street, why not take itself public and sell 100% of the new shares to retail customers? Who needs Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan ?

title: Remember Last Year's 7 p.m. Cheer? Some New Yorkers Are Still at It.
summary: Resume Subscription. Early in the pandemic, New Yorkers began cheering for essential workers every evening at 7. From windows and balconies, they clapped, yelled, blew horns and banged pots and pans, letting it all out for the men and women facing down the deadly virus with little more than a flimsy mask.

title: Women Didn't Need Zoom to Speak Up in the Office
summary: Nor do they need special guidance now.. It is ironic that Jennifer Nason, global chairman of investment banking at J.P. Morgan , is still harping on the false narrative that women need guidance on how to participate in meetings ("The Zoom Revolution Empowers Women to Speak Up," op-ed, July 3). This is both insulting to women and untrue.

title: New York Goes After the Trump Organization
summary: Diversion of time and resources for political advantage is a derogation of duty to apply the law where warranted-not where desired.. Regarding your editorial "Indicting the Trump Organization" (July 3): The targeting in this investigation of an individual, Donald Trump, for political purposes by the Manhattan district attorney and New York state attorney general is appalling. As a former chief counsel of the Internal Revenue Service, appointed by President Jimmy Carter, I know well the responsibility that those charged with the administration of penal laws have to enforce them fairly. The selective use of investigatory and prosecutorial powers to advance partisan political purposes is an abuse of dangerous proportions.

title: Canada Tests the Limits of Radical Mimicry
summary: Activists express a most un-Canadian impulse to copy their American neighbors in the happy business of tearing down and starting over.. Regarding Lawrence Krauss's "Canadians Follow U.S. Lead in Ripping Down Statues" (op-ed, July 1): That a past misdeed-what country does not have some black marks in its history?-should give rise to an almost immediate negation of Canada's founding indicates a deeper malaise.

title: 'If Public Schools Were Allowed to Have a Backbone'
summary: We wouldn't need school choice.. Lost in your editorial "School Choice Marches Ahead" (July 3) is the irony that if public schools were run properly, there would be no need for vouchers, charter schools and the like. As Jason Riley has pointed out in your pages, public schools are hamstrung by state regulations that lead to classroom chaos. And where there is no order, there is no learning. Yet school administrators often cannot exclude students-even temporarily-who disrupt those who want to learn; they must be kept in class rather than disciplined or suspended. Those who want to make something of themselves are at the mercy of those who are there to have fun and be disruptive.

title: Finding New Funds for the Interstate Highway System
summary: We need to rebuild and upgrade the interstates without delay.. In "Congress Debates Infrastructure but Ignores the Interstates" (op-ed, July 1), Robert Poole reminds us all of the vital importance of the Interstate Highway System for our economy and daily lives. He also reminds us of the pressing need to rebuild and upgrade it without delay.

title: Richard Branson's Space Flight: What You Need to Know
summary: What's all the fuss? How did it happen? How far did he go? Here are the answers to those questions. Richard Bransonflew to the edge of space on Sunday aboard a rocket-powered plane, 22 years after he created the Virgin Galactic brand that aims to lead a brand-new tourism industry.

title: Djokovic Wins Wimbledon, Tying Federer and Nadal With 20 Major Titles
summary: The world's No. 1 player beat Matteo Berrettini in four sets for his sixth win at the All England Club. WIMBLEDON, England-Novak Djokovic has spent his entire professional career chasing two men he was never supposed to catch.

title: ProPublica's Tax-Records 'Scoop' Isn't All Bad for the IRS
summary: Misleading analysis of stolen documents was good for the agency's funding prospects.. Holman Jenkins argues "The IRS Is ProPublica's Accessory" (Business World, July 7) in the publication of stolen tax documents from thousands of Americans. ProPublica uncovered no crimes but even much-ado-about-nothing revelations that the wealthy do not pay nonexistent taxes support the narrative that the rich game the system. Journalists are mostly mum about the apparent breach of security at the IRS, but seized upon the bipartisan infrastructure bill's $40 billion in new IRS funding as necessary to catch more crooks. ProPublica's amateurish and misleading analysis was good for IRS funding prospects. Maybe that's why the agency has been silent about the release of confidential tax data.

title: Elon Musk Has a Ticket to Space, Too...With Richard Branson's Virgin
summary: Ahead of Branson's blastoff Sunday, Virgin Galactic said fellow billionaire has a ticket. LONDON-As Richard Branson's Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc. and Jeff Bezos' Blue Origin LLC race their respective billionaires into space, Elon Musk, a third billionaire pursuing space tourism, already has his own ticket-with Virgin Galactic.

title: Biden Stakes Out Position in Debate Over Power of Big Companies
summary: Body of academic research shows U.S. economy has become less competitive as power swells in large firms, but not everyone agrees. Behind President Biden's executive order seeking to curb the power of companies that dominate their markets is a body of academic research that finds the U.S. economy has become less competitive in the past two decades as power swells in large firms.

title: Shipping Delays and Higher Rates Get Small Businesses Jammed Up
summary: Small importers bear the brunt of snarled supply chains; '$17,000 and it won't move until September'. Long waits for merchandise deliveries and crippling costs are hobbling the efforts of small and midsize businesses across the U.S. to benefit from the economic recovery after a difficult year.

title: How Google's and Apple's Free Password Managers Compare With 1Password, Dashlane and Others
summary: Free password managers built into popular browsers may work for some, including kids and less tech-savvy loved ones, but they come with some downsides-mainly, where you can or can't use them. With ransomware attacks on the rise-and compromised passwords to blame for some of the hackings-there's no better time to review your personal security practices.

title: Banks Are in the Economy's Waiting Room
summary: Good news on credit and capital have propelled bank stocks this year, but that might run out of steam. Banks have done a lot to put themselves in a position to benefit from higher rates. Now investors just have to wait.

title: Higher Inflation Is Here to Stay for Years, Economists Forecast
summary: Strong economic rebound and lingering pandemic disruptions fuel inflation forecasts above 2% through 2023, survey finds. Americans should brace themselves for several years of higher inflation than they've seen in decades, according to economists who expect the robust post-pandemic economic recovery to fuel brisk price increases for a while.

title: Global Tax Deal Heads Down Perilous Path in Congress
summary: Business groups urge delay as U.S. lawmakers prepare for complex two-step process. WASHINGTON-A complex international corporate tax deal that took years to hammer out soon faces one of its toughest tests: the U.S. Congress.

title: From Google to Roblox, How One Young Tech Worker Is Building Her Dream Career
summary: Most Popular News. At 26, Andrea Fletcher has already worked for Google, Apple and Roblox. She says her career in software engineering really began with a childhood love of logic puzzles that involve math and patterns. Then, as a senior in high school, thanks to a gentle nudge from her dad, she opted to take a computer-science elective over art.

title: Elon Musk Is Called to Defend Tesla's Purchase of SolarCity
summary: Plaintiffs allege that the billionaire entrepreneur led Tesla to overpay for SolarCity in 2016. Mr. Musk has defended the deal.. In 2016, Elon Musk had two unprofitable businesses on his hands in Tesla and SolarCity Corp. His solution to improve their outlook: combine them into a single clean-energy business.

title: Binance Froze When Bitcoin Crashed. Users Want Their Money Back.
summary: The world's largest crypto exchange has no headquarters, making it difficult for disgruntled traders to complain about the May crash. Anand Singhal built up $50,000 in savings from the time he was 13 doing freelance coding from his bedroom in New Delhi. It was meant to pay for a dream-a master's degree in computer science in the U.S. The money disappeared in seven minutes on May 19.

title: Young Americans Aren't Getting Vaccinated, Jeopardizing Covid-19 Fight
summary: Slow uptake of Covid-19 shots among 18-to-29-year-olds is complicating mass vaccination campaign; U.S. ramps up outreach to young adults. Millions of Americans have rolled up their sleeves to get vaccinated against Covid-19, but one group is well behind: young adults.

title: How Dollar Tree Sells Nearly Everything for $1, Even When Inflation Lurks
summary: Discount chain bets it can manage rising wages and shipping rates by tinkering with selection and trimming costs. Dollar Tree Inc. is famous for selling most of its products-from a pair of flip flops to a small bottle of detergent-for a dollar apiece.

title: Heat Wave Hit Northwest Businesses
summary: Farms and stores in Oregon and Washington are still recovering and assessing the damage from last month's record-high temperatures. COOK, Wash.-As a heat wave bore down on the Pacific Northwest two weeks ago, Bob Turik and his team of scientists hauled 350,000 Chinook salmon by truck to get them into cooler waters they needed to survive.

title: Earnings Kick Off With Sky-High Forecasts, Record Stock Market
summary: With stock valuations sitting above long-term norms, investors will be looking to company executives for clues on future profits. Wall Street is heading into earnings season this week with high expectations after strong profits fueled a stock market rally in the first half of the year.

title: Australia's Delta Outbreak Shows Vaccines Protect Against Hospitalization
summary: Figures are in line with evidence from other countries, including the U.K. and Israel. SYDNEY-Early data from Australia's outbreak of the Covid-19 Delta variant suggest that two vaccine doses offer significant protection against severe illness and hospitalization.

title: The Seemingly Unstoppable Grand Slam Summer of Novak Djokovic
summary: The world No. 1 takes Wimbledon and closes in on a historic tennis accomplishment. The U.S. Open awaits. He could add a gold medal in Tokyo, too, but he's unsure if he'll go.. Until further notice, the biggest drama in tennis, and perhaps all of sports, is: Will anyone stop Novak Djokovic?
